reviews.review_text: We view a funeral, political scandal, attempted rape, news scoop that is swiftly thwarted, symphony composition, and double murders - through the minds and black hearts of many.  More than a page turner. More like a barn burner. The end - what the hell? Tense, terse, driving, relentless.

as a fan of mcewan’s writing, i bought this book shortly after the publication release.  about a year ago, while scanning titles in my home library and seeing Amsterdam, i realized that i couldn’t recall what the book was about, and i had a feeling that i didn’t understand it.  i buy books from used book stores and at library sales, so i have plenty of unread books.  i put Amsterdam in the pile of unread books, my intention being to read the book again.  a few days ago, i began rereading the book. i read the opening pages aloud.  a woman died, her body cremated. outside the crematorium are her husband and three former lovers, a politician, a composer and a newspaper editor.  the four men are points on a square with the woman as point in the center connecting to them.  of the lines of the square, connecting the four men, three are solid, one missing, presenting an equation to be solved.  near the end of the book, a conversation between the composer and a conductor applies equally to the musical composition and the plot composition with ‘the amoral inevitability of pure geometry’. … “Clive wanted the great conductor to bless his symphony with a lofty compliment and angled a question accordingly: ‘Do you think the whole piece is hanging together well?  Structurally, I mean.’ “it does hang together well, and in conclusion those two points connect as the fourth line, solving the equation.  however, mathematical puzzles and structural integrity are different animals.  the conclusion is constructed of flimsy material, translated in literary language, what starts out as serious fiction ends with an action so subtle in execution as to be silliness.  one can spend endless hours attempting to make sense of it, perhaps in a moral context, perhaps as karma or even as divine comedy, or one can accept it as a fitting ending without asking why and accepting that in the realm of fiction this is the turn mcewan wanted to apply and leave it at that.

Starts interestingly, soars high during the first and second act and the finale is a letdown. Agree with other critics that the language is great, and makes me want to re-read several lines, and I might re-visit some passages - the ones that describe human nature, and aligns it to nature in general, there are several quote-worthy passages here.However, the ending, though is a neat twist, seems out of character. It seems forced.One might justify it as dark comedy or something similar, but still, there is a lack of a strong buildup towards this finale - much like Clive's composition.
I really wanted to like this book, but I couldn't get into it. The premise was interesting, but the story dragged and then turned downright ridiculous. I do not recommend it.
The plot took an interesting, almost humorous twist.  The author is a talented writer.  I read it years ago and read it again after recommending it to my book club.
Quirky and entertaining, a good read.
An excellent example of the surprise-ironic ending, and of course a biting commentary on the literary/artistic pretensions of the high-culture celebrity class.

The story was compelling to a point but the ending was apparent before the end.  Were each of the two protagonists so self-absorbed that they didn't have any suspicions about the actions of the other?
I fail to understand why there are so many great reviews on this book. The story is rather choppy, the ending is ridiculous, first 70% of the book the exposition.

summary:
The Booker Prize-winning contemporary morality tale—cleverly disguised as a comic novel—from the acclaimed author of Atonement.

On a chilly February day, two old friends meet in the throng outside a London crematorium to pay their last respects to Molly Lane. Both Clive Linley and Vernon Halliday had been Molly's lovers in the days before they reached their current eminence: Clive is Britain's most successful modern composer, and Vernon is a newspaper editor. Gorgeous, feisty Molly had other lovers, too, notably Julian Garmony, Foreign Secretary, a notorious right-winger tipped to be the next prime minister.

In the days that follow Molly's funeral, Clive and Vernon will make a pact with consequences that neither could have foreseen…
